The **Twenty-second Amendment** (**Amendment XXII**) of the [United States
Constitution](/wiki/United_States_Constitution "United States Constitution")
limits the number of times one can be elected to the office of [President of
the United States](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States "President of the
United States"). Congress proposed the amendment by two-thirds of both the
House and Senate on March 21, 1947.
[Ratification](/wiki/Article_Five_of_the_United_States_Constitution#Ratification
"Article Five of the United States Constitution") by the requisite 36 of the
then-48 states was completed on February 27, 1951.

## Text[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Twenty-
second_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Text")]

> **Section 1.** No person shall be elected to the office of the President
> more than twice, and no person who has held the office of President, or
> acted as President, for more than two years of a term to which some other
> person was elected President shall be elected to the office of the President
> more than once. But this article shall not apply to any person holding the
> office of President when this article was proposed by the Congress, and
> shall not prevent any person who may be holding the office of President, or
> acting as President, during the term within which this article becomes
> operative from holding the office of President or acting as President during
> the remainder of such term.
>
> **Section 2.** This article shall be inoperative unless it shall have been
> ratified as an amendment to the Constitution by the legislatures of three-
> fourths of the several states within seven years from the date of its
> submission to the states by the Congress.

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Twenty-
second_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: History")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Ulysses_S._Grant_1870-1880.jpg/220px-
Ulysses_S._Grant_1870-1880.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ulysses_S._Grant_1870-1880.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ulysses_S._Grant_1870-1880.jpg "Enlarge")

Ulysses S. Grant narrowly lost his party's nomination, and chance for a third
term in 1880.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Wilson_at_Harding_Funeral.jpg/177px-
Wilson_at_Harding_Funeral.jpg)](/wiki/File:Wilson_at_Harding_Funeral.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Wilson_at_Harding_Funeral.jpg "Enlarge")

Woodrow Wilson, pictured in 1923, deadlocked the Democratic convention in
1920, but was not nominated. He wished to run again in 1924, but lacked
support and died before the convention.

Although the Twenty-second Amendment was clearly a reaction to [Franklin D.
Roosevelt](/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt "Franklin D. Roosevelt")'s service as
President for an unprecedented four terms, the notion of presidential term
limits has long-standing roots in American politics. The [Constitutional
Convention of 1787](/wiki/Constitutional_Convention_\(United_States\)
"Constitutional Convention \(United States\)") considered the issue
extensively, although it ultimately declined to restrict the amount of time a
person could serve as president. But following [George
Washington](/wiki/George_Washington "George Washington")'s decision to retire
after his second elected term, numerous public figures subsequently argued he
had established a "two-term tradition" that served as a vital check against
any one person, or the presidency as a whole, accumulating too much power.[1]

In his [Farewell Address](/wiki/George_Washington%27s_Farewell_Address "George
Washington's Farewell Address"), written near the end of his second term,
Washington both reveals he considered not standing for reelection in
1792,[Note 1] and that his decision not to seek a third term in 1796 was due
to age, not intention to set precedent. Eleven years later, [Thomas
Jefferson](/wiki/Thomas_Jefferson "Thomas Jefferson") further contributed to
the convention of a voluntary two-[term limit](/wiki/Term_limit "Term limit")
when he wrote in 1807, "if some termination to the services of the chief
Magistrate be not fixed by the Constitution, or supplied by practice, his
office, nominally four years, will in fact become for life."[2] Three of the
next four presidents after Jefferson—[James Madison](/wiki/James_Madison
"James Madison"), [James Monroe](/wiki/James_Monroe "James Monroe"), and
[Andrew Jackson](/wiki/Andrew_Jackson "Andrew Jackson")—served two terms, and
each one adhered to the two-term principle.

In spite of the strong two-term tradition, a few presidents prior to Franklin
Roosevelt did attempt to secure a third term. [Ulysses S.
Grant](/wiki/Ulysses_S._Grant "Ulysses S. Grant"), after having served as
[president from 1869 to 1877](/wiki/Presidency_of_Ulysses_S._Grant "Presidency
of Ulysses S. Grant"), sought nomination for another term at the [1880
Republican National Convention](/wiki/1880_Republican_National_Convention
"1880 Republican National Convention"), but narrowly lost to [James
Garfield](/wiki/James_Garfield "James Garfield"), who would go on to win the
[1880 election](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1880 "United States
presidential election, 1880"). Given the Republican Party's dominance during
that period, had Grant been nominated, he might well have won a third term.

[Theodore Roosevelt](/wiki/Theodore_Roosevelt "Theodore Roosevelt") succeeded
to the presidency on September 14, 1901, following [William McKinley's
assassination](/wiki/Assassination_of_William_McKinley "Assassination of
William McKinley") (194 days into his second term), and was subsequently
elected to a full term in
[1904](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1904 "United States
presidential election, 1904"). While he declined to seek a third (second full)
term in 1908, Roosevelt did seek one four years later, in the [election of
1912](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1912 "United States
presidential election, 1912"), where he lost to [Woodrow
Wilson](/wiki/Woodrow_Wilson "Woodrow Wilson"). Wilson himself sought
nomination to a third term in 1920, at the [Democratic National
Convention](/wiki/1920_Democratic_National_Convention "1920 Democratic
National Convention");[3] he deliberately blocked the nomination of the former
[Secretary of the Treasury](/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_the_Treasury
"United States Secretary of the Treasury"), his son-in-law [William Gibbs
McAdoo](/wiki/William_Gibbs_McAdoo "William Gibbs McAdoo"), the front-runner.
Although seriously ill at the time, Wilson anticipated that the party would
side with their sitting president were the convention deadlocked. Wilson was
too unpopular even within his own party at the time, and [James M.
Cox](/wiki/James_M._Cox "James M. Cox") was nominated. He would again
contemplate running for a nonconsecutive third term in 1924, devising a
strategy for his comeback, but again lacked any support and died at the
beginning of the year.[4]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/1944_portrait_of_FDR_%281%29.jpg/260px-1944_portrait_of_FDR_%281%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:1944_portrait_of_FDR_\(1\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:1944_portrait_of_FDR_\(1\).jpg "Enlarge")

[Franklin D. Roosevelt](/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt "Franklin D. Roosevelt"),
pictured in August 1944, was elected to both a third and fourth term, the only
president to serve more than eight years.

Franklin D. Roosevelt spent the months leading up to the [1940 Democratic
National Convention](/wiki/1940_Democratic_National_Convention "1940
Democratic National Convention") refusing to state whether he would seek a
third term. His Vice President, [John Nance Garner](/wiki/John_Nance_Garner
"John Nance Garner"), along with [Postmaster
General](/wiki/United_States_Postmaster_General "United States Postmaster
General") [James Farley](/wiki/James_Farley "James Farley"), announced their
candidacies for the Democratic nomination. When the convention came, Roosevelt
sent a message to the convention, saying he would run only if
[drafted](/wiki/Draft_\(politics\) "Draft \(politics\)"), saying delegates
were free to vote for whomever they pleased. The delegates issued 946 votes
for Roosevelt, 72 for Farley, and 61 for Garner; they replaced Garner with
[Henry A. Wallace](/wiki/Henry_A._Wallace "Henry A. Wallace") as the vice
presidential nominee, and Farley resigned as postmaster general. In the [1940
general election](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1940 "United
States presidential election, 1940"), while Republican [Wendell
Willkie](/wiki/Wendell_Willkie "Wendell Willkie") received six million more
votes than the previous Republican candidate ([Alfred
Landon](/wiki/Alfred_Landon "Alfred Landon")) had in 1936, Roosevelt still won
decisively, taking 38 of 48 states. His supporters cited impending war as a
reason for breaking with precedent, while Willkie had run against the
principle of a third term. Roosevelt was the first president elected to a
third term, and remains the only one to exceed eight years in office.

Four years later, in the [election of
1944](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1944 "United States
presidential election, 1944"), Roosevelt defeated New York governor [Thomas E.
Dewey](/wiki/Thomas_E._Dewey "Thomas E. Dewey") to win an unprecedented fourth
term. While he effectively quelled rumors of his poor health during the
campaign, Roosevelt's health was in reality deteriorating. On April 12, 1945,
only 82 days after his [fourth
inauguration](/wiki/Fourth_inauguration_of_Franklin_D._Roosevelt "Fourth
inauguration of Franklin D. Roosevelt"), he suffered a [cerebral
hemorrhage](/wiki/Cerebral_hemorrhage "Cerebral hemorrhage") and died.

Near the end of the 1944 campaign, Thomas Dewey announced support of an
amendment that would limit future presidents to two terms. According to Dewey,
"four terms, or sixteen years (which is what Roosevelt would have served had
he lived until 1949), is the most dangerous threat to our freedom ever
proposed."[5] The Republican-controlled [80th
Congress](/wiki/80th_United_States_Congress "80th United States Congress")
approved a [Joint resolution](/wiki/Joint_resolution "Joint resolution")
"proposing an amendment to the Constitution relating to the terms of office of
the president". in March 1947;[6] it was signed by Speaker of the House
[Joseph W. Martin](/wiki/Joseph_William_Martin,_Jr. "Joseph William Martin,
Jr.") and acting President pro tempore of the Senate [William F.
Knowland](/wiki/William_F._Knowland "William F. Knowland").[7] The
ratification process for the 22nd Amendment was completed on February 27,
1951, 7003143900000000000♠3 years, 343 days after it was sent to the states.
The new amendment's [2-term limit](/wiki/Term_limit "Term limit") did not
apply (due to the [grandfather clause](/wiki/Grandfather_clause "Grandfather
clause") in Section 1) to the [incumbent](/wiki/Incumbent "Incumbent")
president, [Harry S. Truman](/wiki/Harry_S._Truman "Harry S. Truman"). He
remained eligible for election to more than two terms.[6]

On November 22, 1963, President [John F. Kennedy](/wiki/John_F._Kennedy "John
F. Kennedy") was assassinated while riding through [Dealey
Plaza](/wiki/Dealey_Plaza "Dealey Plaza") in downtown [Dallas](/wiki/Dallas
"Dallas"), [Texas](/wiki/Texas "Texas"). Vice President [Lyndon B.
Johnson](/wiki/Lyndon_B._Johnson "Lyndon B. Johnson"), who was also in the
motorcade, three cars back, was unhurt. Upon Kennedy's death, Johnson
[became](/wiki/First_inauguration_of_Lyndon_B._Johnson "First inauguration of
Lyndon B. Johnson") the nation's 36th president, and served out the remaining
7002425000000000000♠1 year, 59 days of Kennedy's term. Under the terms of the
22nd Amendment, Johnson, who ran for and won a full four–year term in
[1964](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1964 "United States
presidential election, 1964") was eligible to run for another full term in
[1968](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1968 "United States
presidential election, 1968") (as he had served less than two years of
Kennedy's term). He chose not to do so, announcing his intentions in a March
31, 1968, speech to the nation, saying, "I shall not seek, and I will not
accept, the nomination of my party for another term as your president."[8] Had
he done so and won, and served the full term (through January 20, 1973), the
total length of his presidency would have been 7003334700000000000♠9 years, 59
days.

## Proposal and ratification[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Twenty-
second_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Proposal and ratification")]

Congress proposed the Twenty-second Amendment on March 21, 1947.[9] The
proposed amendment was adopted on February 27, 1951.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/22nd_Amendment_Pg1of1_AC.jpg/220px-22nd_Amendment_Pg1of1_AC.jpg)](/wiki/File:22nd_Amendment_Pg1of1_AC.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:22nd_Amendment_Pg1of1_AC.jpg "Enlarge")

Archives](/wiki/National_Archives_and_Records_Administration "National
Archives and Records Administration")

subsequently ratified by the following states:

The following states took no action to consider the amendment:

  2. Kentucky

(Neither [Alaska](/wiki/Alaska#Statehood "Alaska") nor
[Hawaii](/wiki/Hawaii_Admission_Act "Hawaii Admission Act") had yet been
admitted as states at the time.)

## Attempts at repeal[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Twenty-
second_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Attempts at repeal")]

According to historian Glenn W. LaFantasie of [Western Kentucky
University](/wiki/Western_Kentucky_University "Western Kentucky University")
(who was opposed to repealing the amendment), "ever since 1985, when [Ronald
Reagan](/wiki/Ronald_Reagan "Ronald Reagan") was serving in his second term as
president, there have been repeated attempts to repeal the Twenty-second
Amendment to the Constitution, which limits each president to two terms."[10]
In early 1989, during an exit interview with [Tom Brokaw](/wiki/Tom_Brokaw
"Tom Brokaw") of [NBC](/wiki/NBC_News "NBC News"), President Reagan stated his
intention to fight for the amendment's repeal.[11] However, after being
diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease in 1994, his post-presidential ambitions
had to be scrapped.

In addition, several congressmen, including Democrats Rep. [Barney
Frank](/wiki/Barney_Frank "Barney Frank"), Rep. [José E.
Serrano](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_E._Serrano "José E. Serrano"),[12] Rep. [Howard
Berman](/wiki/Howard_Berman "Howard Berman"), and Sen. [Harry
Reid](/wiki/Harry_Reid "Harry Reid"),[13] and Republicans Rep. [Guy Vander
Jagt](/wiki/Guy_Vander_Jagt "Guy Vander Jagt"),[14] Rep. [David
Dreier](/wiki/David_Dreier "David Dreier")[15] and Sen. [Mitch
McConnell](/wiki/Mitch_McConnell "Mitch McConnell")[16] have introduced
legislation to repeal the Twenty-second Amendment, but each resolution died
before making it out of its respective committee. Other alterations have been
proposed, including replacing the absolute two term limit with a limit of no
more than two consecutive terms and giving Congress the power to grant an
exemption to a current or former president by way of a
[supermajority](/wiki/Supermajority "Supermajority") vote in both
houses.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_]

On January 4, 2013, Rep. José E. Serrano again introduced a resolution
proposing an Amendment to repeal the Twenty-second Amendment, as he had done
every two years since 1997; he did not do so during the [114th
Congress](/wiki/114th_United_States_Congress "114th United States
Congress").[17][18]

## Interaction with the Twelfth Amendment[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Twenty-
second_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Interaction with the Twelfth Amendment")]

There is a point of contention regarding the interpretation of the Twenty-
second Amendment as it relates to the [Twelfth
Amendment](/wiki/Twelfth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution "Twelfth
Amendment to the United States Constitution"), ratified in 1804, which
provides that "no person constitutionally ineligible to the office of
President shall be eligible to that of Vice President of the United States".

While it is clear that under the Twelfth Amendment the original constitutional
qualifications of age, citizenship, and residency apply to both the President
and Vice President, it is unclear whether a two-term president could later
serve as Vice President. Some argue that the Twenty-second Amendment and
Twelfth Amendment bar any two-term president from later serving as Vice
President as well as from succeeding to the presidency from any point in the
[United States presidential line of
succession](/wiki/United_States_presidential_line_of_succession "United States
presidential line of succession").[19] Others contend that the Twelfth
Amendment concerns qualification for _service_ , while the Twenty-second
Amendment concerns qualifications for _election_ , and thus a former two-term
president is still eligible to _serve_ as vice president.[20][21] The
practical applicability of this distinction has not been tested, as no former
president has ever sought the vice presidency, although in 1980, former
president [Gerald Ford](/wiki/Gerald_Ford "Gerald Ford") was mentioned as a
possible running mate for Republican presidential nominee [Ronald
Reagan](/wiki/Ronald_Reagan "Ronald Reagan") and there were some negotiations
between the two camps. Nothing ever became of the idea,[22] and had Ford been
selected, he would have still been eligible for election as President, as he
had only served less than one full term in finishing out [Richard
Nixon](/wiki/Richard_Nixon "Richard Nixon")'s second term. During [Hillary
Clinton's 2016 candidacy](/wiki/Hillary_Clinton_presidential_campaign,_2016
"Hillary Clinton presidential campaign, 2016"), she jokingly said that she had
considered naming Bill Clinton as her Vice President, but had been advised it
would be unconstitutional.[23] Others contend that a "termed out" President
would be eligible to ascend to the Presidency via Presidential succession
rules given the text's explicit reference to election.[24]

The Constitution does not restrict the number of terms a person can serve as
Vice President.[25]

## Affected individuals[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Twenty-
second_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Affected individuals")]

The amendment explicitly did not apply to the sitting president ([Harry S.
Truman](/wiki/Harry_S._Truman "Harry S. Truman")) at the time it was proposed
by Congress. Truman, who had served nearly all of Franklin D. Roosevelt's
unexpired fourth term and who had been elected to a full term in
[1948](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1948 "United States
presidential election, 1948"), was thus eligible to seek re-election in 1952.
However, after poor performance in the [1952 New Hampshire
primary](/wiki/New_Hampshire_primary#Winners_and_runners-up "New Hampshire
primary"), Truman chose not to seek his party's nomination. He theoretically
also would have been eligible in later elections.

Since the amendment's ratification, [Dwight D.
Eisenhower](/wiki/Dwight_D._Eisenhower "Dwight D. Eisenhower"), [Richard M.
Nixon](/wiki/Richard_M._Nixon "Richard M. Nixon"), [Ronald
Reagan](/wiki/Ronald_Reagan "Ronald Reagan"), [Bill
Clinton](/wiki/Bill_Clinton "Bill Clinton"), [George W.
Bush](/wiki/George_W._Bush "George W. Bush"), and [Barack
Obama](/wiki/Barack_Obama "Barack Obama") have been elected president twice.
The same party has won the presidency in three consecutive elections only once
since World War II, when Republican [George H. W.
Bush](/wiki/George_H._W._Bush "George H. W. Bush") won in
[1988](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1988 "United States
presidential election, 1988") after two terms as Vice President with
Republican [Ronald Reagan](/wiki/Ronald_Reagan "Ronald Reagan"). In all other
cases, the opposing party's candidate has won after two terms with a single
party: [Dwight D. Eisenhower](/wiki/Dwight_D._Eisenhower "Dwight D.
Eisenhower") (R) in 1952, [John F. Kennedy](/wiki/John_F._Kennedy "John F.
Kennedy") (D) in 1960, [Richard Nixon](/wiki/Richard_Nixon "Richard Nixon")
(R) in 1968, [Jimmy Carter](/wiki/Jimmy_Carter "Jimmy Carter") (D) in 1976,
[Bill Clinton](/wiki/Bill_Clinton "Bill Clinton") (D) in 1992, [George W.
Bush](/wiki/George_W._Bush "George W. Bush") (R) in 2000, [Barack
Obama](/wiki/Barack_Obama "Barack Obama") (D) in 2008, and [Donald
Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump") (R) in 2016. The only president who
took office after the ratification of the Twenty-second Amendment and who
could have served more than eight years was [Lyndon B.
Johnson](/wiki/Lyndon_B._Johnson "Lyndon B. Johnson").[26][27] He became
President in 1963 when [John F. Kennedy was
assassinated](/wiki/Assassination_of_John_F._Kennedy "Assassination of John F.
Kennedy"), served the final 14 months (less than two years) of Kennedy's term,
was elected president in
[1964](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1964 "United States
presidential election, 1964"), and ran briefly for re-election in 1968 but
chose to withdraw from the race. [Gerald Ford](/wiki/Gerald_Ford "Gerald
Ford") became president on August 9, 1974, and served the final 29 months
(more than two years) of [Richard Nixon](/wiki/Richard_Nixon "Richard
Nixon")'s unexpired term. Ford, who lost to Jimmy Carter in
[1976](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1976 "United States
presidential election, 1976"), would have been eligible to be elected in his
own right only once.

Since Ford's death in 2006, the only former presidents who remain technically
eligible to seek another term are [Jimmy Carter](/wiki/Jimmy_Carter "Jimmy
Carter") (elected in [1976](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1976
"United States presidential election, 1976"), defeated in
[1980](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1980 "United States
presidential election, 1980")) and [George H. W. Bush](/wiki/George_H._W._Bush
"George H. W. Bush") (elected in
[1988](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1988 "United States
presidential election, 1988"), defeated in
[1992](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1992 "United States
presidential election, 1992")); both are now nonagenarians and neither has
announced any plans to ever run again.

qa.question: when was the 22nd amendment proposed and ratified

nq_65637_14.Query Analysis: The query seeks the dates when the 22nd Amendment to the U.S. Constitution was proposed and ratified.
nq_65637_14.Answer Analysis: The answer provides the specific dates: proposed on March 21, 1947, and ratified on February 27, 1951.
nq_65637_14.Document Content Analysis: The document discusses the history of term limits in the United States, from the Articles of Confederation to the U.S. Constitution, and mentions the 22nd Amendment in the context of establishing a two-term limit for the presidency.
